channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: ‘Just Because I Have a Car Doesn’t Mean I Have Enough Money to Buy Food’
item.description: The economic strain of the coronavirus pandemic has more Americans turning to food banks and charity for help feeding their families.
item.dc:creator: Tim Arango and Brenda Ann Kenneally

item.title: Efforts to Channel Protests Into More Votes Face Challenges in Kenosha
item.description: Some Black residents of Kenosha, upended by the police shooting of Jacob Blake, weren’t convinced that an election would solve the problem.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: “Let’s say I did go out and vote and I voted for Biden,” said Michael Lindsey, a friend of Mr. Blake’s who protested for several nights after the shooting. “That’s not going to change police brutality.”

item.title: The Portland Protests: What This Teenager Learned
item.description: Last summer was all about dance team and teen parties. But after she watched George Floyd’s death in a video on her phone, Daria Allen’s world drastically changed.
item.dc:creator: Kate Conger
item.media:credit: Octavio Jones for The New York Times
item.media:description: Daria Allen is one of many protesters who have rallied nightly for racial justice in downtown Portland, Ore.

item.title: Mississippi Wants Magnolia to Be Centerpiece of New State Flag
item.description: A committee finished its search for a flag to replace the one with a Confederate emblem that had flown for 126 years. It now moves to a statewide ballot.
item.dc:creator: Giulia McDonnell Nieto del Rio and Rick Rojas
item.media:credit: Rogelio V. Solis/Associated Press
item.media:description: The winning design for the new Mississippi state flag was displayed last month outside the Old Capitol Museum in Jackson, Miss.

item.title: In Louisiana, Love for a Chinese Restaurant and Its Magnetic Owner
item.description: For years, Lucky Palace has drawn fans for its intriguing wine list. Now, they come to help their dear friend Kuan Lim in his time of need.
item.dc:creator: Brett Anderson
item.media:credit: Zerb Mellish for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kuan Lim started learning about wine in order to attract gamblers from the casinos that surround Lucky Palace, in Bossier City, La. He became a passionate expert, and is widely admired for his generosity and taste.

item.title: California's Heat Wave Will Be Dangerously Hot This Weekend
item.description: Record-breaking temperatures are expected across the western United States. They might be followed by wind that could worsen fires in California, or storms that could bring snow in Colorado.
item.dc:creator: Jacey Fortin
item.media:credit: Jose Carlos Fajardo/Bay Area News Group, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Triple-digit temperatures are expected across much of California over the Labor Day weekend.

item.title: Vaping Links to Covid Risk Are Becoming Clear
item.description: Researchers are starting to home in on the ways in which the use of e-cigarettes raises the chances of catching the virus, and suffering its worst effects.
item.dc:creator: Katherine J. Wu
item.media:credit: John Francis Peters for The New York Times
item.media:description: While in the hospital for vaping-related lung illness that collapsed a lung, Janan Moein was told he had a 5 percent chance of survival.

item.title: Why Facebook’s Blocking of New Political Ads May Fall Short
item.description: There are still many ways that voter misinformation can spread on the social network, even as it moves to cut off new political ads on Oct. 27.
item.dc:creator: Davey Alba and Sheera Frenkel
item.media:credit: Jim Wilson/The New York Times

item.title: Biden Condemns Report That Trump Called Fallen Soldiers ‘Losers’
item.description: Responding to a report in The Atlantic that the president had called soldiers killed in combat “losers,” Joe Biden cited his own son’s military service and said such remarks were “un-American.”
item.dc:creator: Thomas Kaplan and Katie Glueck
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times
item.media:description: Joseph R. Biden Jr. criticized President Trump in a speech that was otherwise focused on the economy.

item.title: After Report That Trump Disparaged War Dead, Democrats See Chance to Win Over Military Voters
item.description: Liberal groups had already ramped up efforts to win over veterans and military families in swing states, where even a small shift could prove decisive.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Steinhauer
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Joseph R. Biden Jr., speaking at a campaign event at a Veterans of Foreign Wars post in Osage, Iowa, in January, hopes to win over a share of military and veteran voters in battleground states.

item.title: Trump Administration Closing Stars and Stripes newspaper
item.description: Stars and Stripes would have ceased print and online publication at the end of the month. A bipartisan group of senators says the Pentagon should find money in its huge budget to continue funding.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: U.S. Signal Corps, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Allied soldiers in London reading copies of Stars and Stripes right off the presses after Germany surrendered in World War II in 1945.

item.title: Overlooked No More: Before Kamala Harris, There Was Charlotta Bass
item.description: She was the first Black woman to run for vice president, in 1952. She was also a pioneering journalist.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Bennett
item.media:credit: Russell Contreras/Los Angeles Public Library, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Charlotta Bass at her desk at The California Eagle, the West Coast’s oldest Black newspaper. She would run for vice president on the Progressive Party ticket.

item.title: Americans Back Tough Limits on Building in Fire and Flood Zones
item.description: A majority support outright bans on construction in disaster-prone areas, as well as paying people to move, researchers say — policies that local governments have been reluctant to adopt.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Flavelle
item.media:credit: Joe Raedle/Getty Images
item.media:description: Damage in Little Chenier, La., after Hurricane Laura. Concerns about building in risky areas are often outweighed by demand for new homes and the jobs that come with them.

item.title: Coronavirus Schools Briefing: Lunch Along With Learning
item.description: Providing free meals is a crucial function for schools.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg and Adam Pasick
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: Cafeteria worker preps lunches at Sinclair Lane Elementary School to feed students and the local community in Baltimore, in April.

item.title: After furor over golf remarks, Trump tweets an old ad of him and Arnold Palmer joking about putting.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Thrush and Andy Newman

item.title: The Service Economy Meltdown
item.description: As companies reconsider their long-term need to have employees on site, low-wage workers depending on office-based businesses stand to lose the most.
item.dc:creator: Eduardo Porter
item.media:credit: Will Matsuda for The New York Times
item.media:description: David Engelsman abruptly lost his job as a restaurant server in Portland, Ore., in March. Now he is fighting to get health insurance for his family.

item.title: Labor Day in California: Dorothea Lange's Iconic Photos of Immigrant Workers
item.description: Friday: A look at the Golden State’s past, and present, in Dorothea Lange’s images of California workers.
item.dc:creator: Jill Cowan

item.title: Jake Auchincloss Wins Massachusetts Primary for Joe Kennedy’s House Seat
item.description: Mr. Auchincloss, a city councilor, won the highly fragmented House race with just 23 percent of the vote, as nine candidates split the electorate.
item.dc:creator: Astead W. Herndon
item.media:credit: Erin Clark/The Boston Globe via Getty Images
item.media:description: Jake Auchincloss narrowly won the Democratic House primary for Massachusetts’s Fourth District, a race that drew nine candidates.

item.title: Jake Auchincloss wins the Massachusetts primary for Joe Kennedy’s House seat.
item.dc:creator: Astead W. Herndon
item.media:credit: Erin Clark/The Boston Globe via Getty Images
item.media:description: Jake Auchincloss won the nine-way Democratic primary with less than 23 percent of the vote.

item.title: Biden says, ‘win or lose, I’m going to go down fighting’ for racial equality.
item.description: Two days after President Trump traveled to Wisconsin to focus attention on violence and disorder, Joe Biden sought to strike a drastically different tone, repudiating the president’s divisive approach to matters of racial injustice.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Katie Glueck
item.media:credit: Kriston Jae Bethel for The New York Times
item.media:description: Joseph R. Biden Jr. prays before the start of a community meeting at Grace Lutheran Church in Kenosha, Wis.

item.title: Trump’s advice to vote twice gives state elections officials new headaches.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Saul and Nick Corasaniti
item.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times
item.media:description: Election workers in Doral, Fla., sorting through mail-in ballots for the state’s primary last month.

item.title: At a rally, Trump says he wants to ‘get along’ with Russia, despite the Navalny poisoning.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Haberman
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump’s comments about Russia came as pressure has increased for him to sound alarms about the poisoning of Aleksei Navalny, a Russian opposition leader.

item.title: What does polling say about which candidate voters trust more to handle the unrest?
item.dc:creator: Giovanni Russonello
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: People gathered near Grace Lutheran Church, where Joseph R. Biden Jr. spoke in Kenosha, Wis., on Thursday.

item.title: New Details About Breonna Taylor’s Life and Death
item.description: ‘The New York Times Presents,’ on FX and Hulu, investigates recordings, 911 calls and over 1,500 pages of police records to reveal a clearer picture of the deadly botched raid.

item.title: What We Know About the Death of Michael Forest Reinoehl, the Portland Shooting Suspect
item.description: The suspect, Michael Forest Reinoehl, 48, was killed by law enforcement agents just five days after the deadly shooting of a right-wing protester.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Ted Warren/Associated Press
item.media:description: Michael Reinoehl was killed by a federally led fugitive task force in Lacey, Wash., on Thursday. He was being investigated in a fatal shooting at a Portland protest.

item.title: Do Voters Trust Trump or Biden More to Handle the Unrest?
item.description: President Trump and Joe Biden have taken starkly divergent approaches to protests and outbreaks of violence in American cities. Gauging whose messaging is more effective has proved challenging for pollsters.
item.dc:creator: Giovanni Russonello

item.title: Mental Illness as a Crime
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Roth and Roth LLP, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Daniel Prude, right, with his brother, Joe.

item.title: Covid-19 Live Updates: U.S. Officials Urge Caution Ahead of Labor Day Weekend
item.description: Russian scientists published the first report on their controversial Covid-19 vaccine, finding a modest amount of antibodies in the volunteers tested.
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: To Many Travelers, 2020 Was the Summer of 1965
item.description: Driving over flying. Domestic destinations. Though the conditions and causes were different, certain midcentury travel preferences experienced a revival this year.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Firshein
item.media:credit: D. Corson/ClassicStock, via Getty Images
item.media:description: On the road again.

item.title: They’re Stuck at Home, So They’re Making Home a Sanctuary
item.description: With few places to go or reasons to spend, those lucky enough to be employed remotely are upgrading their surroundings. The impulse comes with guilt.
item.dc:creator: Maria Cramer and Aimee Ortiz
item.media:credit: Brittainy Newman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Michelle Iorio turned her new house into a haven from a world that was especially dangerous for her and others with compromised immune systems.

item.title: Bar and Medical Exam Delays Keep Graduates in Limbo
item.description: Many recent graduates can’t practice their professions without passing a licensing exam, but those tests have been disrupted for months by the coronavirus pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Emma Goldberg
item.media:credit: Amr Alfiky/The New York Times
item.media:description: Leslie Caraballo, who graduated from law school in the spring, had planned to study for the bar while her young children were at school and summer camp.

item.title: ‘Voting Is My Healing’: Inside a Push to Turn Out 100,000 Crime Survivors
item.description: For all that narratives about crime shape American politics, survivors are rarely at the center of the conversation, if they are heard at all. A campaign called #HealTheVote is trying to change that.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Astor
item.media:credit: Lauren Justice for The New York Times
item.media:description: Over the next nine weeks, a campaign will train local organizers to ensure that crime survivors know where and how to vote.

item.title: Cleveland Police Officer Is Shot and Killed
item.description: A second person was also killed, a police union official said. Details were scarce, and the police were still gathering evidence, he said.
item.dc:creator: Elaine Yu
item.media:credit: Tony Dejak/Associated Press
item.media:description: Police officers in downtown Cleveland in June. A city detective who was shot and killed on Thursday had been sworn in as one of the F.B.I.’s violent crimes task force officers the day before.

item.title: Trump Denies Calling Fallen Soldiers ‘Losers’ and ‘Suckers’
item.description: A report in The Atlantic said the president called troops killed in combat “losers” and “suckers.” He strenuously denied it, but some close to him said it was in keeping with other private comments he has made disparaging soldiers.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker and Maggie Haberman
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump on Thursday night in Pennsylvania. “It’s a fake story and it’s a disgrace that they’re allowed to do it,” he told reporters on Friday in the Oval Office, referring to the Atlantic article.

item.title: This Labor Day, These Workers Are Trying to Stay Afloat
item.description: The coronavirus pandemic has brought various hardships. An artist, bookseller, comedian and five others share their stories of how they are coping with all the uncertainty.
item.category: Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts
item.media:credit: Maridelis Morales Rosado for The New York Times
item.media:description: Caitlyn McCain, artistic associate at New York City Children's Theater, in her neighborhood, Ditmas Park, Brooklyn.

item.title: Art Basel Miami Beach Is Canceled
item.description: Organizers, concerned at the state of the pandemic in South Florida, put off the event until next year.
item.dc:creator: Brett Sokol
item.media:credit: Casey Kelbaugh for The New York Times
item.media:description: Visitors at the Bass Museum during the Art Basel fair in Miami Beach in December 2018.

item.title: Louisiana Man Faces Murder Charge in Fatal Shooting of a Panhandler
item.description: A Black victim’s family seeks a federal investigation into how the police have handled a shooting after a confrontation with a white man.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor

item.title: Suspect in Fatal Portland Shooting Is Killed by Officers During Arrest
item.description: Law enforcement agents killed Michael Forest Reinoehl while trying to arrest him, four officials said. He was being investigated in the fatal shooting of a supporter of a far-right group.
item.dc:creator: Hallie Golden, Mike Baker and Adam Goldman
item.media:credit: Joshua Bessex for The New York Times
item.media:description: Michael Reinoehl was killed by a federally led fugitive task force in Lacey, Wash., on Thursday. He was being investigated in a fatal shooting at a Portland protest.

item.title: As Others Condemn Putin Critic’s Poisoning, Trump Just Wants to ‘Get Along’
item.description: At a rally on Thursday, President Trump did not mention the dissident Aleksei A. Navalny, or warnings that Moscow is trying to interfere with the election. When news reports mention Russia, he said, “I just turn it off.”
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley and Maggie Haberman
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: “If I get along with Russia, is that a good thing or bad thing?” President Trump asked the crowd at a rally on Thursday in Latrobe, Pa. “I think it’s a good thing.”

item.title: Jessica Krug: University Investigates Claim That White Professor Pretended to Be Black
item.description: George Washington University said it was looking into a blog post written under the name of Jessica A. Krug detailing a long history of deception about her racial identity.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson and Jennifer Schuessler
item.media:credit: Mary F. Calvert for The New York Times
item.media:description: A history professor at George Washington University revealed in a blog post to claiming a Black identity, which was not her identity at birth.

item.title: Netanyahu Privately Condoned U.S. Plan to Sell Arms to U.A.E., Officials Say
item.description: The package being pushed by the Trump White House — which could shift the military balance in the Middle East — includes an electronic warfare plane, the EA-18G Growler.
item.dc:creator: Mark Mazzetti, Edward Wong and Michael LaForgia
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Tal Shahar
item.media:description: President Trump’s announcement of a diplomatic breakthrough between Israel and the United Arab Emirates came as Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel was trying to manage multiple crises.

item.title: Biden, in Kenosha, Makes Case for Healing and Unity, Not Division
item.description: Two days after President Trump traveled to Wisconsin to focus attention on violence and disorder, Joe Biden sought to strike a drastically different tone, repudiating the president’s divisive approach to matters of racial injustice.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Katie Glueck
item.media:credit: Kriston Jae Bethel for The New York Times
item.media:description: Joseph R. Biden Jr. held a community event at Grace Lutheran Church in Kenosha, Wis., on Thursday.

item.title: Student Charged in Cyberattacks at Miami-Dade Schools
item.description: Virtual classes in the fourth-largest school district in the United States were choked by glitches this week. A 16-year-old high school junior has admitted to the cyberattacks.
item.dc:creator: Jacey Fortin
item.media:credit: Cristobal Herrera-Ulashkevich/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: The police believe that more people may have been involved in cyberattacks at the Miami-Dade schools this week.

item.title: Transgender People Face New Legal Fight After Supreme Court Victory
item.description: Though the Supreme Court embraced a broad definition of sex in June, the Department of Health and Human Services pressed ahead with changes that narrowed the definition of sex in the Affordable Care Act.
item.dc:creator: Alisha Haridasani Gupta
item.media:credit: James Estrin/The New York Times
item.media:description: Cecilia Gentili, left, and Tanya Walker in Manhattan in August.

item.title: Buffy Wicks Voted on the Floor With a Newborn in Her Arms
item.description: The California state assemblywoman brought her month-old baby to the chamber — and instantly became an image of moms who do it all.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Medina
item.media:credit: California State Assembly, via Associated Press

item.title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Lies Ahead
item.description: Will the virus resurge with a vengeance?
item.dc:creator: Lara Takenaga and Jonathan Wolfe
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: Irving Kanarek, Lawyer Who Defended Charles Manson, Dies at 100
item.description: The national spotlight that focused on Mr. Kanarek made his disruptive circus of courtroom tactics almost as fascinating as his bizarre clients.
item.dc:creator: Robert D. McFadden
item.media:credit: Associated Press
item.media:description: Irving Kanarek, right, in 1970 with Charles Manson, whom he defended in the macabre killings of the actress Sharon Tate and six other people.

item.title: Robert Pattinson Tests Positive for Coronavirus, Halting ‘Batman’ Production
item.description: Work on the film first shut down in March because of the pandemic, which has staggered the entertainment industry.
item.dc:creator: Aimee Ortiz and Nicole Sperling
item.media:credit: Jordan Strauss/Invision, via Associated Press
item.media:description: “The Batman,” which had been filming outside London, stars Robert Pattinson.

item.title: Voting Twice? Trump Creates a New Headache for Election Officials
item.description: They say he is sowing confusion about systems that already have robust checks against fraud.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Saul and Nick Corasaniti
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump, speaking at a ceremony in Wilmington, N.C., encouraged Americans to try to vote multiple times, which is illegal.
